questions.question: Metal spheres, each of radius 2 cm, are packed into a rectangular box of internal dimensions 16 cm × 8 cm × 8 cm. When 16 spheres are packed the box is filled with preservative liquid. Find the volume of this liquid. Give your answer to the nearest integer. [Use $\pi = 3.14$]
questions.solution:
Given:

  • Radius of each sphere ($r$) = 2 cm
  • Dimensions of the rectangular box ($L \times B \times H$) = $16 \text{ cm} \times 8 \text{ cm} \times 8 \text{ cm}$
  • Number of spheres ($n$) = 16

Step 1: Calculate the volume of the rectangular box.

$$V_{box} = L \times B \times H$$

$$V_{box} = 16 \times 8 \times 8 = 1024 \text{ cm}^3$$

Step 2: Calculate the volume of one sphere.

$$V_{sphere} = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3$$

$$V_{sphere} = \frac{4}{3} \times 3.14 \times (2)^3$$

$$V_{sphere} = \frac{4}{3} \times 3.14 \times 8 = \frac{100.48}{3} \approx 33.493 \text{ cm}^3$$

Step 3: Calculate the total volume of 16 spheres.

$$V_{total\_spheres} = 16 \times 33.493 \approx 535.89 \text{ cm}^3$$

Step 4: Calculate the volume of the liquid.

The liquid fills the empty space in the box.

$$V_{liquid} = V_{box} - V_{total\_spheres}$$

$$V_{liquid} = 1024 - 535.89 = 488.11 \text{ cm}^3$$

Rounding to the nearest integer, the volume is 488 cm³.

questions.question: A storage tank is in the form of a cube. When it is full of water, the volume of water is 15.625 m³. If the present depth of water is 1.3 m, find the volume of water already used from the tank.
questions.solution:
Given:

  • Volume of full tank ($V$) = 15.625 m³
  • Present depth of water ($h_{present}$) = 1.3 m

Step 1: Find the side length of the cubical tank.

Let the side of the cube be $a$.

$$a^3 = 15.625$$

$$a = \sqrt[3]{15.625} = 2.5 \text{ m}$$

So, the total height of the tank is 2.5 m.

Step 2: Calculate the volume of water used.

The volume of water used corresponds to the empty part of the tank.

Height of empty part ($h_{used}$) = Total Height - Present Depth

$$h_{used} = 2.5 - 1.3 = 1.2 \text{ m}$$

Volume used = Area of base $\times$ Height used

$$V_{used} = (a \times a) \times h_{used}$$

$$V_{used} = (2.5 \times 2.5) \times 1.2$$

$$V_{used} = 6.25 \times 1.2 = 7.5 \text{ m}^3$$

Alternatively, Volume used = Total Volume - Present Volume

$$V_{used} = 15.625 - (2.5 \times 2.5 \times 1.3) = 15.625 - 8.125 = 7.5 \text{ m}^3$$

questions.question: Find the amount of water displaced by a solid spherical ball of diameter 4.2 cm, when it is completely immersed in water.
questions.solution:
Concept: According to Archimedes' principle, the volume of water displaced by a solid completely immersed in it is equal to the volume of the solid.

Given:

  • Diameter of spherical ball ($d$) = 4.2 cm
  • Radius ($r$) = $4.2 / 2 = 2.1$ cm

Step 1: Calculate the volume of the sphere.

$$V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3$$

$$V = \frac{4}{3} \times \frac{22}{7} \times (2.1)^3$$

$$V = \frac{4}{3} \times \frac{22}{7} \times 9.261$$

$$V = \frac{88}{21} \times 9.261$$

$$V = 88 \times 0.441$$

$$V = 38.808 \text{ cm}^3$$

Thus, the amount of water displaced is 38.808 cm³.

questions.question: How many square metres of canvas is required for a conical tent whose height is 3.5 m and the radius of the base is 12 m?
questions.solution:
Given:

  • Height ($h$) = 3.5 m
  • Radius ($r$) = 12 m

Step 1: Calculate the slant height ($l$).

$$l = \sqrt{r^2 + h^2}$$

$$l = \sqrt{(12)^2 + (3.5)^2}$$

$$l = \sqrt{144 + 12.25} = \sqrt{156.25}$$

$$l = 12.5 \text{ m}$$

Step 2: Calculate the Curved Surface Area (CSA).

Canvas required = CSA of the cone

$$CSA = \pi r l$$

$$CSA = \frac{22}{7} \times 12 \times 12.5$$

$$CSA = \frac{22}{7} \times 150$$

$$CSA = \frac{3300}{7} \approx 471.43 \text{ m}^2$$

questions.question: Two solid spheres made of the same metal have weights 5920 g and 740 g, respectively. Determine the radius of the larger sphere, if the diameter of the smaller one is 5 cm.
questions.solution:
Given:

  • Weight of larger sphere ($W_1$) = 5920 g
  • Weight of smaller sphere ($W_2$) = 740 g
  • Diameter of smaller sphere ($d_2$) = 5 cm $\Rightarrow$ Radius ($r_2$) = 2.5 cm

Concept: Since the spheres are made of the same metal, their densities are equal. Therefore, the ratio of their weights is equal to the ratio of their volumes.

$$\frac{W_1}{W_2} = \frac{V_1}{V_2}$$

Step 1: Set up the ratio.

$$\frac{5920}{740} = \frac{\frac{4}{3}\pi r_1^3}{\frac{4}{3}\pi r_2^3}$$

$$8 = \left(\frac{r_1}{r_2}\right)^3$$

Step 2: Solve for $r_1$.

Taking the cube root of both sides:

$$2 = \frac{r_1}{r_2}$$

$$r_1 = 2 \times r_2$$

$$r_1 = 2 \times 2.5 = 5 \text{ cm}$$

The radius of the larger sphere is 5 cm.

questions.question: A school provides milk to the students daily in cylindrical glasses of diameter 7 cm. If the glass is filled with milk up to a height of 12 cm, find how many litres of milk is needed to serve 1600 students.
questions.solution:
Given:

  • Diameter of glass = 7 cm $\Rightarrow$ Radius ($r$) = 3.5 cm
  • Height of milk ($h$) = 12 cm
  • Number of students ($n$) = 1600

Step 1: Calculate the volume of milk in one glass.

$$V = \pi r^2 h$$

$$V = \frac{22}{7} \times 3.5 \times 3.5 \times 12$$

$$V = 22 \times 0.5 \times 3.5 \times 12$$

$$V = 11 \times 42 = 462 \text{ cm}^3$$

Step 2: Calculate total volume for 1600 students.

$$V_{total} = 1600 \times 462 = 739200 \text{ cm}^3$$

Step 3: Convert to litres.

$$1000 \text{ cm}^3 = 1 \text{ Litre}$$

$$V_{litres} = \frac{739200}{1000} = 739.2 \text{ Litres}$$

questions.question: A cylindrical roller 2.5 m in length, 1.75 m in radius when rolled on a road was found to cover the area of 5500 m². How many revolutions did it make?
questions.solution:
Given:

  • Length/Height of roller ($h$) = 2.5 m
  • Radius ($r$) = 1.75 m
  • Total Area covered = 5500 m²

Step 1: Calculate the Curved Surface Area (CSA) of the roller.

The area covered in one revolution is equal to the CSA.

$$CSA = 2\pi r h$$

$$CSA = 2 \times \frac{22}{7} \times 1.75 \times 2.5$$

$$CSA = 2 \times 22 \times 0.25 \times 2.5$$

$$CSA = 44 \times 0.625 = 27.5 \text{ m}^2$$

Step 2: Calculate the number of revolutions.

$$Revolutions = \frac{\text{Total Area}}{\text{Area per revolution}}$$

$$Revolutions = \frac{5500}{27.5}$$

$$Revolutions = \frac{55000}{275} = 200$$

questions.question: A small village, having a population of 5000, requires 75 litres of water per head per day. The village has got an overhead tank of measurement 40 m × 25 m × 15 m. For how many days will the water of this tank last?
questions.solution:
Given:

  • Population = 5000
  • Requirement per head = 75 litres/day
  • Tank dimensions = $40 \text{ m} \times 25 \text{ m} \times 15 \text{ m}$

Step 1: Calculate total daily water requirement.

$$Daily\_Req = 5000 \times 75 = 375000 \text{ litres}$$

Convert to cubic metres ($1 \text{ m}^3 = 1000 \text{ litres}$):

$$Daily\_Req = \frac{375000}{1000} = 375 \text{ m}^3$$

Step 2: Calculate the volume of the tank.

$$V_{tank} = 40 \times 25 \times 15$$

$$V_{tank} = 1000 \times 15 = 15000 \text{ m}^3$$

Step 3: Calculate the number of days.

$$Days = \frac{V_{tank}}{Daily\_Req}$$

$$Days = \frac{15000}{375} = 40$$

questions.question: A shopkeeper has one spherical laddoo of radius 5 cm. With the same amount of material, how many laddoos of radius 2.5 cm can be made?
questions.solution:
Given:

  • Radius of big laddoo ($R$) = 5 cm
  • Radius of small laddoo ($r$) = 2.5 cm

Step 1: Relate the volumes.

Let $n$ be the number of small laddoos.

$$Volume_{big} = n \times Volume_{small}$$

$$\frac{4}{3}\pi R^3 = n \times \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3$$

$$R^3 = n \times r^3$$

Step 2: Solve for $n$.

$$n = \frac{R^3}{r^3} = \left(\frac{R}{r}\right)^3$$

$$n = \left(\frac{5}{2.5}\right)^3 = (2)^3 = 8$$

So, 8 small laddoos can be made.

questions.question: A right triangle with sides 6 cm, 8 cm and 10 cm is revolved about the side 8 cm. Find the volume and the curved surface area of the solid so formed.
questions.solution:
Concept: When a right triangle is revolved about one of its legs, it forms a right circular cone.

Given:

  • Revolved about side = 8 cm $\Rightarrow$ Height ($h$) = 8 cm
  • Base radius ($r$) = 6 cm
  • Hypotenuse ($l$) = 10 cm (Slant height)

Step 1: Calculate the Volume.

$$V = \frac{1}{3}\pi r^2 h$$

$$V = \frac{1}{3} \times \frac{22}{7} \times (6)^2 \times 8$$

$$V = \frac{1}{3} \times \frac{22}{7} \times 36 \times 8$$

$$V = \frac{22}{7} \times 12 \times 8 = \frac{2112}{7} \approx 301.71 \text{ cm}^3$$

Step 2: Calculate the Curved Surface Area (CSA).

$$CSA = \pi r l$$

$$CSA = \frac{22}{7} \times 6 \times 10$$

$$CSA = \frac{1320}{7} \approx 188.57 \text{ cm}^2$$
